question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
From 1(a) we saw that the equations for the planes \(S_1\) and \(S_2\) are

\[\begin{aligned} 2x_1+x_2-x_3&=1\\ x_1+x_2&=1.\end{aligned}\]

This precisely the equation form of the line since any \(x_1,x_2\) and \(x_3\) that satisfy this will be on both planes and therefore be on the line of intersection.

statement_html:
Let \(S_1\) be the plane perpendicular to \(\mathbf{n}=[2,1,-1]\) and through the point P=[1,-1,0]. Let \(S_2\) be the plane through the points A=[1,0,0], B=[-1,2,1], C=[0,1,1]. By L, we denote the line of intersection of \(S_1\) and \(S_2\).

Determine L in equation form.
